data.title: #44 Send in the Robot Fire Brigade! - BOSAI: Science that Can Save Your Life
data.meta_description: The world's first robot fire brigade has been developed in Japan. See how these incredible robots equipped with AI can tackle large-scale fires in areas that are inaccessible to humans.
data.text:
00:01

Fire and black smoke billow up.

00:07

This large-scale fire at an oil refinery was caused by an earthquake.

00:15

The fire spread from tank to tank, making firefighting efforts extremely difficult.

00:23

I thought I might actually die here today.

00:31

These kinds of large-scale fires can occur all over the world.

00:38

This scientist was prompted into action.

00:44

We started R&D on robots for use in places where humans cannot go,

00:48

to lessen the impact of disasters and help us get back to normal.

01:02

They developed the world's first robot fire brigade.

01:09

Four robots equipped with artificial intelligence that can make decisions on their own

01:14

and work together to extinguish a fire.

01:20

Let's take a look at the amazing new technology behind the robot fire brigade.

01:37

Ichihara is one of Japan's leading industrial cities, with several oil refineries.

01:45

It's also home to the world's first robot fire brigade.

01:50

Hello.

01:51

Hello.

01:54

Dr. Hisanori AMANO developed the robot fire brigade.

02:01

Is it the big vehicle I can see over there?

02:05

Yes, that big fire engine transports all the robots together.

02:12

It's making a dynamic entrance.

02:18

This is the transport vehicle for the robot fire brigade.

02:25

There are four robots inside.

02:29

Oh, that's impressive.

02:35

Up close, they're bigger than I expected.

02:42

Development was prompted by the Great East Japan Earthquake of 2011,

02:50

when a magnitude 9 earthquake caused buildings to collapse and triggered a tsunami that killed over 15,000 people.

03:04

Ichihara City, about 400 kilometers from the epicenter, also suffered major damage.

03:15

A tank at the oil refinery caught fire.

03:19

The fire continued to burn for more than 10 days as it spread to other tanks.

03:29

The fire couldn't be readily extinguished because firefighters couldn't get close to it,

03:34

due to the risk of explosion.

03:38

The firefighters were very courageous,

03:41

but there comes a point where humans can't go any further.

03:51

So in 2014, Amano started developing a robot that can fight fires in dangerous places that humans cannot access.

04:01

Five years later, the world's first robot fire brigade was completed.

04:08

The most important feature is that

04:10

the robots work together to carry out a coordinated firefighting operation.

04:18

There are four robots, divided into a reconnaissance team and a firefighting team.

04:28

First, a drone-type robot is deployed.

04:35

The drone assesses the situation with a bird's-eye view.

04:44

It detects the fire source with visible-light and thermal imaging cameras,

04:50

and will automatically approach to take a closer look.

04:55

By overlaying the normal image and the thermal image,

04:59

we can see which areas are hotter.

05:06

However, the closer it gets to the fire, the more turbulent the airflow becomes.

05:11

It's important to ensure stability in the air.

05:17

The drone has two sets of propellers.

05:25

By rotating the upper and lower propellers in opposite directions,

05:29

it's possible to generate strong propulsive force even in hot airflow.

05:36

Its on-board thermal sensor and gas sensor help automatically determine

05:40

whether there is any danger of hot airflow or explosion.

05:46

This protects the drone itself, so it can collect and transmit information to the ground robot.

05:57

The role of the ground robot is to identify a safe route for the water cannon robot.

06:04

It uses a laser to check for obstacles.

06:11

If there's an obstacle, it can fold up its wheels

06:17

and change to tracks.

06:27

It can overcome the obstacles.

06:33

In this way, the robot makes its own decisions and gathers information about the site of the fire.

06:43

The truck that carries the robots is used as the command vehicle.

06:49

Please be careful.

06:55

There are lots of monitors.

06:58

This is the ground reconnaissance robot.

07:00

This is the drone reconnaissance robot.

07:02

The images they take are displayed here.

07:08

The data is used to create a firefighting plan.

07:14

First the location of the fire source is entered onto a map of the site that has been loaded in advance.

07:23

The system then calculates the distance from the fire source, and suggests potential locations for the water cannon.

07:30

In this case, there are two possible locations: A and B.

07:38

Next, it shows possible routes to the water release point using red and green lines.

07:46

Then, the human controller makes the final decision on which location to use for the water cannon, and which route to take.

08:03

I don't think everything should be done automatically.

08:07

It's important that a human who understands the situation

08:12

makes the final decision and takes responsibility.

08:18

Once a firefighting plan is decided,

08:21

the water cannon robot and hose extension robot are deployed.

08:28

By using a hose extension robot, the hose can be used up to 300 meters from the fire hydrant.

08:38

The hose is neatly deployed from the back.

08:47

It's finally time to release the water.

08:53

Oh, that's great. It goes up high.

09:01

It's spraying water further and further away.

09:07

The effective range is 70 meters, about three times that of a normal fire engine.

09:16

It's much smaller than a typical fire engine.

09:19

How can it withstand such high water pressure?

09:25

It's heavy.

09:27

This creates a large amount of frictional force.

09:33

The robot weighs 1.5 tons.

09:36

This means it can release 4 tons of water per minute.

09:43

The reconnaissance robot takes pictures from above

09:48

to see if water is reaching the desired locations.

09:53

If it is missing its target, the reconnaissance robot transmits the correct location to the water cannon robot,

10:02

and it corrects automatically.

10:07

We've done some research to see if just one robot could do everything.

10:14

But here we're carrying out one big firefighting operation

10:20

by dividing up the roles.

10:24

Heat from the fire is a danger to these robots.

10:29

If it gets too hot, the electronic equipment will stop working.

10:34

So this is what Amano devised.

10:38

The secret is this silver material.

10:44

His team developed a special material called aluminum-coated fiber.

10:49

It can reflect 95% of the heat.

10:54

The entire robot is covered with this material.

11:02

The back side is designed to deal with the remaining 5% of the heat.

11:08

It's like a mesh.

11:09

It looks like ordinary material, but it's very important.

11:16

By spraying water from inside the robot's body, the remaining 5% can be canceled out.

11:37

Like a sprinkler.

11:40

That's what's happening inside.

12:02

In fires caused by oil, foam-like extinguishing fluid is used to cut off airflow.

12:11

However, this kind of foam is easily blown away by the wind and is difficult to control.

12:18

We've developed a special nozzle.

12:25

The aqueous solution acts like a pipe,

12:30

protecting and delivering the foam to the desired location.

12:44

The newly developed nozzle envelops the foam used for extinguishing fires in an aqueous solution.

12:55

The solution is heavier than the foam and more wind-resistant,

12:59

so it's now possible to target the foam at the fire more accurately than before.

13:10

The robot fire brigade was completed in 2017, and has been used in real life situations.

13:21

In 2022, a sulfur dioxide gas leak occurred at a chemical plant.

13:28

High concentrations of sulfur dioxide gas are dangerous for humans and make it difficult to breathe.

13:36

It was too risky for firefighters to get close.

13:41

I was at the scene.

13:44

There was a strong smell and it was frightening.

13:48

The robot fire brigade was called into action.

13:53

By approaching the site and vigorously spraying it with water,

13:57

they were able to disperse the toxic gas and reduce its concentration to a safe level.

14:05

Robots are very useful,

14:08

and will continue to be important partners in the field.

14:14

Amano would like to further expand the scope of the robot fire brigade's activities.

14:22

This system only exists here in Japan.

14:26

I hope these robots can be used to suit other local circumstances.

14:42

A robot fire brigade equipped with artificial intelligence that can operate in areas where humans cannot go:
